159603908.review:
This game could be so fantastic, but unfortunately it's monotonous and boring and WAY too expensive for what it offers.
(In my opinion it's worth a maximum of €20)
Everything said in the trailer is just extremely exaggerated

You CAN have multiple Zombots... 2 of them (after you progress in the main quest), that's all you get!!!!!
With specific upgrades in the skill tree, your Zombots CAN have up to 2 Zombots each (so 6 total), BUT they're just dumb Zombots with no armor or weapons (these do almost no damage), so they're just useless and just meat shields.
They are also very stupid and usually don't do what you want them to do. Pathfinding can be annoying in some places.

There are buildings to build that in normal survival games are just chests and workbenches.

They do work for you? You set up a beacon that requires energy to operate you have to produce first. So you can only build a very limited number of them since there are only three “fuel” points on the map, these are just wooden sticks that you burn for energy. Set how many Zombots have to work there, and then you never have to go back there again.

The enemies are fun and some can be tough, but overall the game is so easy that there is no challenge at all, which makes it very boring very quickly. I play with the bow and can kill groups of 20 zombies without even getting hit and with no zombies protecting me, with ease.

The fast travel spots are placed in strange places and result in a lot more "walking simulator" (or let's call it what it is) "content stretching" than necessary (which also makes it more boring quicker).

Weapon progression is not good at all. I still shoot almost every zombie with the bow.
Some have to be killed in melee so I use a spear to fight them, but there aren't many that require you to fight in melee, all can be killed in ranged combat, some only have armor so you do less damage , so you COULD even play the whole game with just ranged combat.

The auto aim is the worst of all, it makes the game so easy even my dog could play it.

Not everything is bad, you will have at least a few hours of fun playing this game.

The biggest problem I have is that it's a finished product (so not early access), so I'm afraid there will only be small hotfixes and no major changes. I hope I'm wrong about that.
Because in its current state I can't recommend it!

159651221.review:
I just don't agree with the negative reviews being posted at all. I'm loving every moment of the game so far, and can't wait to play it co-op with people. The humor is on point, the base building isn't extensive, but it serves the purpose it is there for very well. I'm loving the "light" survival crafting feel of it.

No stupid fiddly little meters to keep happy, no boring weapon durability, just you, your zombie bros, and a stick vs the world. I don't regret the money spent at all.

159751273.review:
I gotta say I was pretty intrigued with the hack and slash style of gameplay for the first 30 minutes. Getting a zombie minon to help mow down hordes was pretty fun too, especially with my coop partner. The game then introduced camp building and pylons which was the peak of excitement for me. Unfortunately it all went downhill after that. 

I think the game has a really neat idea, and tries to bring a lot of cool mechanics to the table. However most of those mechanics are short sighted, and lacking the depth needed to make them fully enjoyable. Ill start with what the game does well.

Hack and slash combat. This game does the mindless combat where you can do silly combinations of things with your minions and partner really well. This doubles down when done as coop. Though I think any more than 2 and the game would become too trivial. Unless the game spawns in zombies per player then that could get bonkers at points. Combat was a 5/5 for me

RPG elements. The skill trees offered are simple, but neat. I opted for full zombot control while my partner dabbled across all three skill trees. It really didnt feel like our playstyles were directed much by the leveling paths we took up until I had 6 zombie minions to her 2. I would say the RPG elements are a 3/5

Tactical/strategy elements. For this I basically just mean the zombot control with a tiny lean into base mechanics. The zombot's were an exciting thing to me. I was in LOVE with Pikmin, and Overlord, and the idea of controlling zombies to do my bidding and keep me safe in the apocalypse was mouth watering. When it got down to it though, I was pretty bummed. Being limited to 1 zombot for about 50% of the game limited my options of tactics, meaning I just had to smack and shoot as much as my partner despite having all my points into my zombies. The zombots have neat automation triggers for in or out of combat, but fine control of them is nonexistant. Once I got to my second zombot, and they controlled two of their own zombots each it started to get quite funny. I didnt have to hack and slash much any more, but that is more because we had 4 zombots with flamethrowers and had very little to do with my extra zombies. A negative side note to the base part of this is the game takes the time to teach you how to capture your zombie, then as soon as you build a camp the pylons can just spawn in up to 9 infinitely. I would have much rather had to go collect each zombie I wanted to control and then leave them at the base. Tactics/Strategy elements were a 1/5 for me in this game

Survival elements. I have very little to say here. Crafting outside of bandages and ammo is basically nonexistant. You can make weapons, but the combat is so spammy and simple that the differences came down to if it was aoe or not and if the damage was high enough to one shot. I just crafted the ranged weapon with the biggest numbers and found a spear and never looked back. Survival elements are a 2/5.

Base building. Awful and pointless. Unclear and wonky hitboxes mean base spacing is inconsistent. There really seems like there is no point with only 1 trap and wall type up to the halfway point of the game. There is really no need to have a camp, not even for your crafting needs because you rarely need to craft, and it could have just been a shop or npc you did it at instead. The prebuilt camps you can fight are built in a way more effective and compact way, making your base feel even worse. It fully feels like it was added just for the purpose of saying it is there and that is it. Having said all that, I am entering the part of the game where you are required to defend your base from zombies, (chapter 4) so maybe the next hour or two will change my mind. As of now Base building is 0/5

Overall the game is not worth what I paid for it ($25). I could see it being a great get at $15 maybe even $20 if you can couch coop or remote play it with a friend. Solo, or if you each have to buy a copy I wouldnt spend more than $10 on it. Especially since they have over 5 cosmetic microtransactions already. This game is a fun little lighthearted couch game to play, I could see kids especially enjoying it with how simple it is.

160147756.review:
Keep in mind, this is for a single player, I have not played Co-op so I can't comment on that. 

I very much enjoyed my time in How to survive 1, I finished that game at least twice, but not so much on How to survive 2, but it was OKish... now Welcome to ParadiZe... I was waiting for this as I liked how it looked, it is very much my type of game, so I pre-ordered. Day of release, I had my beer ready, after work, time to relax! I open the game and at first launch the game felt very nice, looked great, played great, fought zombies, started the story and I was feeling good about this game! fast forward 12 hours in game later and well the truth is that the game is just very boring, the only gimmick is that you can kinda control zombies, but trust me, that wears off very quick! the game is full of these tiny things that irritate you in the worst kinda way, you can sometimes clip over some walls by rolling, but you can't get out unless you destroy the wall, the animations of the cut scenes are just horrible, I don't care much about that in particular, but I do hate that I cannot fast forward the dialog, either you watch the whole cut scene or skip it completely, if you choose to watch the cut scene, then sometimes the characters stop talking for a few seconds... then they continue, but you don't fully know if the dialog is over so you end up skipping half of the dialog scenes, not that it matters, the story is just plain simple, there is no meat and no real interest to find out about it other than to continue with the same missions as the missions all seem to be the exact same with minor variations, the enemy variation is meh at best, I have fought only 2 bosses, and they were as easy as they come they were more of a nuance than a real fight. The game feels easy and there is no way to change difficulty, most of the times I've died is because of stupid mistakes by me. The UI looks nice, but its very cumbersome to use. Building is VERY limited, it seems they want this to be part of the endgame, I guess for some reason they think people will keep playing the horde mini game after they complete the game? There is absolutely no survival elements present, the food and water just give you some healing and some of them status effects, but they are absolutely not necessary.  I am not sure if I have it in me to finish this game, but if I do and something changes my mind I will edit this comment. 

Maybe they should have not wasted so much time trying to create day 1 cosmetic DLC  and focused on QOL improvements

159925445.review:
i'm always kinda baffeld nowadays by the expectations people got; there's no other explanation for some of the reviews on steam atleast. 

it's a very fun, cute, little top down arpg. it's not a survival, Ark or whatnot zombie game, no Project Z, etc. . 
you control your mc from a fixed top down perspective, do action combat (quite good actualy), with a wide variety of melee and ranged weapons, you find and craft new gear (armor, weapons) and build (very basic) a little base and ressource extractors to partake (later on) in some basic base def. 
the main focus of the game is the exploration, combat and power progression. and it clicks after a while. it's fun to explore rare corners of the map to find some unique (looking aswell) armor piece, or some lore (tongue and cheek). it's quite fun to mow down hordes of zombies and collect the drops afterwards (crafting mats mostly). this cycle worked in many other games aswell..nothing new on this front, but what is here is very competent. 

the "twist" or what makes it kinda special are your zombots. think A.I. controlled drones, just...well zombies. you can capture one early on and use him as your companion. in a basic menu you can equip him/her to serve specific funtions and you get a wide variety of on/off A.I. commands, like to collect in and/or out of combat or to heal you or to taunt, etc. 
then you discover the "expert"-mode and realise that you can do even more to adjust your zombie drone. you will get more, i think it's 2 later on. thanks to the ingame skill tree these zombie drones can also "hack" (control) their very own zombie drones. which is just fun. it's a fantastic little feature. beeing it the wobbly zombie animations or em running around to collect some leaves for you...it's endearing. 
similiarly you can build seperate pylons which can control up to 3 zombots for you. these can serve as a base-patrol-defense, they can work as ressource extractors (to collect wood for your generator for example).
there are some minor pathing issues but apart from that i have had a lot of fun with this system and i still think it's a great addition.
it's pretty telling that the skill-tree is mostly power-ups (and modified new funtions) for your zombots and not your mc. your own toon gets stronger via gear. which can also be upcrafted. like finding a basic pumpgun to get it to a very rare or legendary status later on, which means more damage basicaly. or by equiping new armor to get higher def. 

technicaly the game isn't Starfield or Cyberpunk but it's nice to look at and ran pretty well on my rig (RTX 3070, i913, 32GB, HDD). about the only technical issue i got is when starting or closing the game, perhaps it's because i got it sitting on an HDD, but there's always a very long black screen (long enough that i think the game crashed everytime). but ingame there's basicaly no loading. it's weird to be sure. my HDD is pretty fast, playing something like Rogue Trader and the loading times are seconds, here it can take a min? but that's the only technical issue i found.

no one cares about the story in these games. but it's kinda here. again very tongue and cheek. some memorable characters, like the nurse (probably in name only) Mary, some not quite hitting jokes about popular figures in real life. the dialogue and great, it ain't terrible either. npc models are a bit sketchy. but again: who plays these games for the plot.

the major isssue i got is the balancing. there's some work to be done here. escort mission are a mess, the npcs you escort pretty much die instantly, which leads to a restart of said mission. you can kinda work around this by clearing the path beforehand...but that's just not great design.
and the base defense missions later on are just plain terrible. doesn't matter much how strong you build your base or the defenses: it's to many enemies and to strong ones. there's whole guides already on how to cheese these missions, cause doing em normaly is beyond frustrating. 
bottom line: balance needs patches.

159566118.review:
Everything is OK'ish. It is at least worth it on sale.

Story: 
It is a little shaky. Seems not so polished, because they continue to animate and have you waiting after the dialog is done. Nothing worthy to remember.

Co-op: 
Never played. Easy enough as it is.

Combat: 
MINDLESSLY slaughtering with button mashing melee or ranged. There are mods to zom-bots which are really the only thing keeping it interesting. Watch your HP drain if you try to melee a zom-bot with spike armor. You can also tweak some settings: when or what your zom-bot strapped with explosives suicides (Tip: they can blow up those metal walls you will run into... or actually them). Also, let your ranged weapon zone-in for that head shot.

Base building: 
Kind of frustrating. You can't remove terrain. If they decided some low bushes are a no-pathing zone then you just need to deal with that. You can't remove trees and nor can your structures. It is ok, but games older have done better. Seems limited to just the forest. Just find a nice wide open area with little entrances to you. You don't need your base near water or wood, because the pylons (zom-bot spawners) can be anywhere on the map (in the forest).


It is ok enough to enjoy.

159626911.review:
It's not bad, but it's not great. I was amused for a while, the humour was a nice touch and it's a fresh take on zombie survival. I laughed out loud when I hopped on the back of a zombie and rode him. Aesthetically, it's a good looking game and runs well but that's about all the positives I can think of.

I haven't finished it but if there's something in my suggestions that's already in the game feel free to point it out and I'll change my review.

The combat needs some more variety. Zombies should hit harder and getting swarmed should be dangerous but instead I'll voluntarily roll into a group and start swinging my bat knocking all the Zs around. Ranged combat felt nice at first. High velocity shots hitting with power that knock enemies around or make them fly if they die but once you realize that ranged weapons can take out groups in no time at all it just becomes a monotonous game of auto aim and fire while walking around. I'd like some skills to add to the weapons, maybe add modifiers to the ammos and weapons to do different things or add an extra skill or two to melee weapons. Blades (or sharpened blades for already bladed weapons) for some bleed chance or insta-decap chance, weights to knock Zs around, fire to set ablaze groups, shocking to electrocute and briefly stun, etc. A sprinting attack and two handed weapons with some ground attacks would be a welcome addition too think. I do love slamming around zombies with a sledgehammer or big axe. 

Speaking of axes, in the wood farming areas (stick spawners) there's an axe right there that you can't take. I was super disappointed. Then I was even more disappointed when I started building my base and the only tree in the middle of it is permanent and has a huge area around it where I can't build anything. Base building feels so restrictive when it comes to building around existing pieces of the world. I understand not being able to cut down trees on the borders of the paths but let us cut down the solo trees for some extra wood, sticks and leaves. 

Setting up material farms is pretty lackluster too. They take up power from your generator, you choose how many Zs to spawn, you give them a couple commands and never come back. Let us have to to give the Zombots axes to smack around trees instead of having them eternally pick up sticks, or have us have to set up defenses or walls for them to help them defend against small hordes or something.

Zombots are a unique mechanic but not very deep. I have no attachment to my zombie companion. Why bother with wasting a skill on being able to revive them when I have 50 more helmets in my inventory. What else am I going to do with that 2000 scrap and 150 broken helmets? They should be given a random name (so we can bond with these lovely beings) and they should level up separately from me, though have them level faster and have a low max level so you don't feel gated into having to keep them. Maybe two types of helmets that pick between our current limited Z or a levelable companion, the latter being a lot more resource intensive to make. Just something to make us choose between wanting to have an actual companion or a disposable self-destructing meat sack that will run into hordes with spiky armour. Maybe give them a small set of skill points and move my skills that boost their skills into their own skill tree. So I can hack a zombie, give him a gun or machete and as he levels I can put points into levelling up his damage, attack speed, health/regen, or even give us the ability to make them a pack mule and add points to help them carry my junk. I'm also a bit disappointed that you don't really equip them with items from your inventory and if they die, the next zombie you hack immediately has the item and armour of the last one. 

Final complaint is more around the NPCs dialogue flow. Their animations are randomly looped and constantly played and make them feel like puppets instead of humans. Bob swinging around his arms opening and closing his laptop 20 times during our conversation was super weird and felt like a lazy design. NPCs need to be less animated during dialog and when they do animate it should be for emphasis or at least related to the context of the conversation.

Overall, like I said it's not bad and definitely has great potential.

I think was hoping for a bit more of a survival element than an this arcadey auto aim filled left click walking simulator.

159867147.review:
You know what?  The game description didn't lie.  You do capture a zombie and have a companion (Eventually two.  Also they each get sub-zombies (and the sub-zombies don't equip anything), so [i]WHOOP DE DOO[/i]).  You do build a base and defend it (it's terrible!).  You do explore the wilderness (a lot!).

Talk about a rather boring and linear game.

Capture one zombie to fight alongside you.  Collect a lot of garbage (wish this were faster/easier to do.  Mashing a button repeatedly for every item is very 2010), trash the garbage to get scrap, use scrap to build your base...!  Woah a base?  Yeah it's like five buildings.  Seriously.  This is the weakest base building in a zombie game, ever, it really shouldn't even be in the game.  Feels tacked on and not very well thought out.

Anyway, run around the map, killing zombies non-stop because zombies, and ... that's the game.  Do fetch quests!  Do more fetch quests!  And of course, fetch quests!  Wowee!

Welcome to Paradize is very repetitive and the gameplay loop is not even that fun.  It could use a lot of work improving itself to be a very good something, not a bunch of little things.  Want to be a base builder?  Improve this, a lot.  Want to be a squad leader?  Improve this, a lot.  Want to be a loot crazy action RPG?  Improve this, a lot.  It does none of these things well and makes the game a yawnfest.

Welcome to Paradize is very braindead, literally.

Overall: 4/10

At First you will be like Oh Cool!!! That's pretty funny! Oh Wow I can ride my zombie!

First couple hours you see a lot of new trinkets and zombie armor types that you can collect! I was like oh man they have some cool Ideas! Can't wait to see what they keep coming up with!

And that was it, hardly anything new after a few hours... Sad panda,

Worst part is the base building... you can't upgrade the base for HOURS.
- Finally get the part you need to upgrade the armory, just small improvements
- Get another upgrade to the power to control a few more zombies
... Then the mini game of hordes attack your base.. horribly implemented. 
In a quest.. base under attack.. go back, kill them, go out again start another quest.. base under attack..

I literally don't even have it in my to finish this game. Bunch of horrible characters, rednecks and dumb gamer humor that lost it's charm. If it had fun game mechanics then sure, but no this isn't it.

159576892.review:
This a *soft* recommend... for now.

Welcome to Paradize is the kind of game I see myself coming to when I don't feel like playing anything else. Mindless button mashing and killing zombies, that's about it. That's a lot less than I was hoping for out of this game when I first came across it.

- The map is very expansive, but feels sort of lifeless beyond moving from objective to objective and the occasional enemy base.

- The UI could be a little better. Some of the gun icons in the inventory look too similar, I find myself hovering over ever gun to determine whether is a pistol, rifle, etc. I'm sure with another 5+ hours they'd start to look a little different, but when I want to change weapons on the fly, it can be difficult, it cant take a second or two.
               - Moving items from your personal inventory to your camp inventory could also be a lot better if I could just Shift + Click on the items I want to move.

- Weapon upgrades. To me, it seems pretty silly to me that you have the ability to upgrade weapons that require XX level to use, when your character is currently below that level. It took me a solid minute, minute and half to figure out why it wouldn't let me equip my upgraded air rifle. Turns out, I was Level 14, and I couldn't equip that upgraded rifle until Level 15. Seems it would just make sense to lock those upgrades until the appropriate level is achieved.

- Melee combat could be a bit better. With how the AI zombies move from time to time, your swings can be wildly mistimed and misplaced. I wish I had the ability to pivot my character mid-swing to adjust for that.

Besides the few downsides, this is a fun game to just hop on and mash away at zombies. But as of right now, that's all I really see this game as: a time killer.

Looking forward to seeing what QoL improvements come over time.

159645342.review:
[h2] Honest Review [/h2]
It's my first time purchasing a game in Early Access and my first time writing a review in English, but I'll do my best to provide reasons to either buy or avoid this new zombies game, Welcome to ParadiZe.

I've had a good time playing both the demo and the full game itself, so I believe I have a solid understanding of what players will encounter in the early stages of the game.

[h2] Important information: [/h2]

Main gameplay mode it's like a campaign mode. So if you're solely interested in playing a survival mode akin to the zombies mode in the Call of Duty Series with friends, that option isn't available at first glance. I hope that the game evolves and then bring us more modes and more challenges. 

[h2] Pro: [/h2]
- Easy to play (either keyboard/mouse or joystick).
- Unique and innovative approach.
- Good translation 
- Many constructions and items.
- RUN USING (O)/(B) IN JOYSTICK IT'S A PRETTY BAD CHOICE. I think that's the only complain about the controls itself. 

[h2] Cons: [/h2]
- Too easy in some moments. Except for a few instances, most of the time, the game feels a bit 'too easy.' It lacks the sense of 'desperation' and 'challenge' that other similar games, such as Project Zomboid and even 7 Days to Die, provide. I'll elaborate more on this in the 'Is it worth buying this game?' section.
- Bad optimization. It's a joke that a game like this requires 12 GB of RAM and sporadically gives errors warning that 'The game will crash,' which are caused precisely by the lack of available RAM on the PC. This is clearly a serious mistake that needs to be fixed if the game wants to reach a large audience. Definitely, a game like this should not require 12 GB of RAM.

So,
[h2] Is it worth buying this game?[/h2]
I paid approximately 18 dollars and I genuinely believe that the game has a lot of potential. Considering its already robust structure and well-established physics and gameplay, that can worth the money if Nacon doesn't abandon this game and creates new modes, maps, etc. (please create a Survival Mode for Multiplayer) This game has the potential to be one of the best ever made in the zombie genre.

But, if they don't improve with more zombots to get and stronger zombies I really think that this game will be a big waste of potential. 

I believe in Nacon. 

Ps: I really thinks that they need to balance the early game. That needs to be harder. Just nerf the damage, put the max health character in 50 and it's done. And then enable more zombots

162746184.review:
[h1]Welcome to Paradize: A Retro-Fueled Adventure with Sunshine, Synthwave, and Sweet Surprises[/h1]

Welcome to Paradize instantly charmed me with its irresistible blend of retro aesthetics, synth-laden soundtrack, and a surprisingly engaging mystery simmering beneath its sunny surface. Developed by solo indie dev, Soleb, this title exudes personality and a distinct passion for the era it lovingly recreates.

[h2]A Trip Back in Time[/h2]

Step into Welcome to Paradize, and you're instantly transported back to the glorious 90s. The low-poly visuals, vibrant neon color palettes, and chunky CRT monitor effects create a nostalgic playground that perfectly captures the visual spirit of the time. Every environment, from the sandy beaches to the dimly lit arcade, oozes authentic retro charm.

The synthwave soundtrack is a standout element, infusing every moment with an infectious energy that propels you forward. Each track expertly balances catchy melodies with a sense of underlying intrigue that hints at something lurking beneath the carefree facade.

[h2]Paradise Has Its Secrets[/h2]

Initially, Welcome to Paradize presents itself as a relaxing and aimless exploration experience. You're free to roam the island, interact with quirky characters, play arcade mini-games, and bask in the nostalgic ambiance. But as you dig a little deeper, the narrative starts to unfold, revealing a central mystery and a surprising level of depth.

Without delving into spoilers, this mystery element kept me thoroughly engaged. Discovering hidden messages, piecing together clues, and encountering increasingly bizarre situations became the driving force behind my playthrough. The narrative strikes a satisfying balance between humor, strangeness, and a touch of the existential that makes it feel entirely unique.

[h2]Gameplay Variety & Unexpected Depth[/h2]

While the visuals and music might be the initial draw, the gameplay in Welcome to Paradize kept me hooked. The island is surprisingly packed with activities.  You can perfect your skills at arcade classics, try your hand at fishing, test your luck with hidden slot machines, or even partake in some impromptu car races.

I was impressed by the amount of hidden content and unlockables scattered throughout the island. Exploration is consistently rewarded, fueling a satisfying sense of discovery and a desire to see everything the game has to offer.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]

Welcome to Paradize took me by surprise. It’s more than just a nostalgic visual treat. This is a surprisingly polished and content-rich experience that weaves a compelling mystery alongside its laid-back, summery vibes. If you have a fondness for retro aesthetics, synthwave music, and enjoy a little strangeness mixed into your games, Welcome to Paradize is a must-play.

160154431.review:
The game makes sense for it's $30 price point. It's bigger than I thought it would be, and there are a lot of options for your zombies that you don't see right off, as the game opens up and you get more equipment for them that causes them to behave differently.

You open up enough new stuff and areas to keep things interesting as you go, so it ended up being one of the few games that I actually finished.

While the zombie skill line is definitely the most interesting, it feels a bit weak compared to what you can learn in the other lines.

There is a skill respec, but I've seen a bug report claiming that using the skill respec makes you lose the extra skill points you picked up in side quests. I haven't verified that the bug exists, and if it does, I assume it will be fixed very soon, but for right now, you may want to watch to see the news around that little hiccup before using respec (I assume this part of the review will be outdated very soon, but it still felt like it should be mentioned).

The base building really isn't very expansive, but you do eventually get more things to put in it. The better defenses don't come until you're extremely deep into the game, though. It's really more about what you can set and program your zombies to do, rather than the base and tower defense parts.

The DLC is a bit overpriced, it should have just came with the game. If you're doing single player, you probably won't care to get it. If you really want to set yourself apart for co-op, then maybe it will be worth it to you.

It doesn't really go super deep, and yet it's still a fun and compelling experience. I base game reviews on the value for their price, and it wouldn't feel like it was right if it was a full priced game, but at half the usual cost, it is well worth the experience for its price tag.

159702957.review:
[h1] The more I played, the less I enjoyed. [/h1]

TLDR: Good initial presentation and premise, very flawed execution due to frustrating combat that lacks depth, base/resource management issues, forgettable maps with awful temperature and traversal mechanics, and weak characters driving a story with basic and annoying quest design.

I'll just list the major issues I had with enjoying this experience with the least amount of spoilers possible. 

Firstly are the zombot companions. The limitations of 2 zombots in their number and gear variety became more obvious as the game stretched on as you cannot upgrade their gear beyond "common" and the health of enemies ballooned with higher levels causing me to fall back on the only major damage and crowd control idea I could come up with which ignored primary weapons completely (mine laying/throwing cannot be mitigated, goes through some walls, destroys structures/groups and simply going up the skill tree allows for tanky, self rez, aggro generators with the downside that they are unreliable sometimes due to pathing sticking to certain buildings and walls, enemies ignoring them even when provoked and cluttering the map with interactable mines). Before that was flamethrowers as they also cannot be mitigated and were good against crowds. The central idea was that I was always looking for something that was guaranteed to work because I had gotten fed up and seeing a melee/ranged zombot waiting for me assist them against an enemy resistant to their weapon-type (dancers are just always immune to ranged???). The frustration of managing their gear became critical in later zones, requiring babysitting the bots for harsh weather effects and traversal demanding changes in one of your only two bots at minimum for entire hours worth of regions. Examples being: the saddle being used to awkwardly cross gaps in harsh weather regions while the zombots just fall into the gaps leaving you alone until you rush to replace them manually or die from weather, gear being used to clear instant death fog that can return even with a player inside of it despite the fog having no real purpose other than instant death hazard that enemies can ignore, and temperature control constantly forcing me to hover around my bots (even when I also need one with a saddle to cross lava???). The final tragedy is that they have zero personality beyond voice/body/gender differences, no reason to be attached to them, no reason to be selective with which ones you control, no regional differences other than clothing and new gear, none of them have interesting mutations or special statistics/preferences for gear, they are not your friends, they are tools that at best can salute you (at the cost of one of their behavior programing allowances).

...Realizing how much time I'm spending on this I'll summarize the rest. 

Maps - Terrain issues causing restarts in the first desert (player stuck) and in chemical zone (zombots under the map, I'm trapped by instant-kill gas and everything else is dead, god help me). Themes are as bare bones as possible, forest, city, desert, swamp, snowy mountains are all filled with uninspiring visuals and forgettable expanses of nothing, landmarks being toppled cars, gravesites with no background information, caves being absolutely devoid of anything meaningful and stretching on painfully, the worst being the final volcano zone that at best... has an amongus reference at the entrance. The charm of a theoretical paradise resort fallen to zombies was realized by games like dead island 12 years ago and the wasted potential of the exact same but with a society built on mind controlled undead with a more comedic and lighthearted approach is simply not fully realized.

Combat - Hit things or shoot things, some times you are forced to do the other or you are instant killed by an explosion or stunlocked from being shot and falling down into being swarmed. You never really feel amazing about combat, there's no complex executions or satisfaction of a fully realized build overcoming a great challenge. The defence of a base relies on chokepoints, mine spam, or similar as entire waves of bomb runners from multiple directions forced me to move my base (a boss can just spawn hazards on top of your zombots that disable your defences and mindcontrols them unless destroyed). Massive levels of explosives, traps, gun wielding, or heavily barricaded enemies made late game agony. Bosses tend to be massive bullet sponges, some requiring specific targeting on parts which zombots fail at and make the fights awkward. Also, no zombie bosses outside of animals, why?

Story/Characters/Quest - I don't remember anyone's name beyond Bob... and that at one point the player character is betrayed by a person they help and is forced to flee, but you never get vengeance, or an explanation, and you just move on. In fact I think basically everyone just bosses you around or is terrible to you for a majority of the time outside Bob's group and "noname" which would be fine if it were funny or entertaining to interact with the characters, but I never felt happy about doing so. All Quest are either fetch quest, an interact with thing here quest, or a kill/destroy quest with sometimes very vague instructions (like an entire region being the zone to search for destructibles) and at worst... [b]  escort quest... WITH TANK CONTROLS?! [/b] Also I just did not enjoy the entire ending sequence.

Okay, I'm too tired to ramble on, there's plenty of more issues (like how mythic weapon rewards are only from base defence, but nothing tells you that...) I don't want to list that loomed over my time with the game. I really wanted to not regret purchasing and spending time on this product, but I just can't say it was worth it, nor would I want someone who thinks any of my explained points would ruin their experience to also have my same regrets.
